effective_dosage: Not applicable (denture use, not a supplement).
study_duration: 6 months (assessed at 24 hours, 30 days, 3 months, and 6 months post-insertion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the non-inferiority of mandibular 2-implant overdentures (IODs) with CAD-CAM milled bars and long distal extensions (MBDE) against conventional IODs on retentive anchors (RA) in terms of chewing efficiency and other outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that mandibular 2-IODs with MBDE were not inferior to conventional IODs on RA in the short term (1 year), with comparable implant survival rates, chewing efficiency, peri-implant bone levels, bite force, and patient-reported outcomes.
population_specificity: Forty edentulous participants rehabilitated with a maxillary conventional denture and a mandibular 2-IOD.

study_goal: To compare the efficacy and treatment outcomes of removable and fixed orthodontic devices in correcting non-skeletal anterior crossbite in children and adolescents.
results_summary: Both removable and fixed devices were equally effective for overjet correction, but fixed devices had shorter treatment times and lower costs. Both types caused inconveniences such as pain, discomfort, and functional difficulties like chewing and speech.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents in mixed dentition with non-skeletal anterior crossbite.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of sialendoscopy with different irrigation protocols (saline or saline/triamcinolone acetonide) on salivary flow and xerostomia in patients with Sjögren's syndrome.
results_summary: Sialendoscopy, regardless of irrigation protocol, increased salivary flow for up to 60 weeks, with significant improvements in unstimulated and chewing-stimulated saliva flow, as well as reduced xerostomia symptoms. The saline/TA group showed particularly notable improvements in chewing-stimulated saliva flow at 48 weeks.
population_specificity: 45 patients with Sjögren's syndrome
effective_dosage: Irrigation with saline or saline/triamcinolone acetonide (specific dosage not detailed)
study_duration: Follow-up assessments up to 60 weeks post-intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the psychophysical and pharmacological properties of gum chewing to understand its pain-relieving effects in burning mouth syndrome (BMS) patients.
results_summary: Gum chewing and simulated chewing significantly reduced pain (VAS scores) in BMS patients. The analgesic effect was linked to lower plasma adrenaline levels and reduced tension-anxiety, suggesting anxiety reduction as a potential mechanism.
population_specificity: 40 women (20 BMS patients and 20 age-matched controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate oral and dental health problems, salivary function, and composition in ulcerative colitis patients and correlate these with disease activity.
results_summary: The study found that hyposalivation was experienced by 16% of patients under resting conditions and 24% under chewing-stimulated conditions, but xerostomia was not correlated with salivary flow rates. Disease activity did not influence salivary amylase and Mucin 5B concentrations, but xerostomia was related to disease activity and quality of life.
population_specificity: 51 ulcerative colitis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient-centered outcomes (pain, discomfort, swelling, chewing difficulty) between laser-assisted flapless corticotomy (LAFC) and piezocision during upper canine retraction.
results_summary: Both LAFC and piezocision caused significant pain, discomfort, swelling, and chewing difficulty at 24 hours post-procedure, but LAFC resulted in less pain and discomfort than piezocision. Symptoms dramatically decreased after the first day, and both groups reported high satisfaction.
population_specificity: 32 patients (19 females, 13 males) with a mean age of 18.25 ± 3.05 years undergoing orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (surgical procedure details provided instead).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 24 hours, 3 days, 7 days, and 14 days post-procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence and associated factors of alcohol use disorder (AUD) in HIV/AIDS patients, including the role of khat chewing as a contributing factor.
results_summary: The study found that khat chewing was significantly associated with AUD in HIV/AIDS patients, with an adjusted odds ratio (AOR) of 3.34. It was identified as one of the qualitative factors linked to higher AUD prevalence.
population_specificity: HIV/AIDS patients, with subgroup analyses for countries like South Africa, Uganda, and Nigeria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of D-Tagatose, alone and combined with xylitol, on the growth of oral bacteria, particularly Streptococcus mutans, to assess its potential for preventing dental caries and oral diseases.
results_summary: D-Tagatose significantly reduced oral bacteria and S. mutans in vitro, but in vivo, only the combination of D-Tagatose and xylitol in chewing gum significantly reduced S. mutans in volunteers' saliva.
population_specificity: 19 healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the ethnomedicinal uses, phytochemical composition, pharmacological activities, and toxicity of Cinnamomum verum, including its applications in chewing gums and other products.
results_summary: The study highlights Cinnamomum verum's broad pharmacological activities, such as antioxidant, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, and antidiabetic effects, but does not specifically quantify its efficacy in chewing-related applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, not a clinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map and evaluate various interventions, including chewing gums/food supplements, to improve oral health in older adults.
results_summary: Most studies (64/81) found statistically significant benefits from interventions, including chewing gums/food supplements, but the heterogeneity of aims, methods, and outcomes limits robust conclusions.
population_specificity: Older adults over 65 years of age, primarily in high-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of experimentally altered mastication (soft-diet feeding, molar extraction, and bite-raising) on hippocampal trophism and function in animal models.
results_summary: Disturbed mastication was associated with reduced hippocampal pyramidal neurons, downregulation of BDNF, reduced synaptic activity, neurogenesis impairment, and poor performance in behavioral tests indicating memory and spatial orientation deficits. Bite-raising was linked to stress, while soft-diet feeding and molar extractions showed inconsistent stress responses.
population_specificity: Animal models (specific species not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing sugar-free gum post-caesarean section could improve gastrointestinal recovery by reducing flatus and defecation times.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in flatus and defecation times between the gum-chewing group and the control or coffee groups, indicating chewing gum was ineffective for this purpose.
population_specificity: 160 primipara pregnant women who underwent caesarean section under spinal anesthesia.
effective_dosage: Chewed sugar-free gum for 15 minutes with an interval of 4 hours from the second postoperative hour.
study_duration: Intervention lasted from the second postoperative hour until gastrointestinal recovery was measured.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the metabolic alterations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) associated with HPV infection, particularly focusing on the role of chewing tobacco as a risk factor.
results_summary: The study highlights that chewing tobacco is a significant risk factor for HNSCC, alongside smoking, alcohol consumption, and HPV infection. It discusses how HPV oncoproteins alter metabolic pathways in HNSCC, distinct from non-HPV associated cases, but does not provide specific outcomes related to chewing tobacco's effects.
population_specificity: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) patients, particularly those associated with HPV infection and chewing tobacco use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the etiological factors of oral cancer, including betel quid chewing, and explore the potential of phytochemicals as chemopreventive agents.
results_summary: The abstract highlights betel quid chewing as a risk factor for oral cancer but does not provide specific results on its effects. It discusses the limitations of traditional treatments and the potential of phytochemicals, though their low bioavailability and targeting remain challenges.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of oral cancer etiological factors and treatments)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of three implant-based treatment strategies (single-implant, two-implant, and fixed 4-implant overdentures) for improving chewing function and patient-reported outcomes in edentulous mandibles.
results_summary: All three implant treatments improved oral health-related quality of life, patient satisfaction, and chewing function compared to baseline, with no significant differences between groups, though effect sizes were slightly lower for the fixed 4-implant group.
population_specificity: Edentulous patients requiring mandibular dentures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of photobiomodulation (PBM) and dexamethasone (DXM) on pain, swelling, and quality-of-life (QOL) in patients undergoing buccal fat pad removal, specifically focusing on chewing comfort.
results_summary: The study found no differences between PBM and DXM groups in pain or edema, but the PBM group reported significantly greater comfort when chewing compared to the DXM group (P < .05).
population_specificity: 20 patients with pseudoherniation of buccal fat pad.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF), associated with areca nut chewing, transforms into oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC).
results_summary: The study highlights the high malignant potential of OSMF (7-13% transformation rate) and discusses varied pathogenic mechanisms, including hypoxia, carcinogenic effects of areca nut, and epithelial-mesenchymal transitions, but does not provide specific efficacy data on interventions.
population_specificity: Individuals with oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF), particularly those who chew areca nut.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of short-term xylitol consumption on pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-8) and Streptococcus mutans counts in the context of oral health.
results_summary: The xylitol group showed significant reductions in gingival and plaque index scores, pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-8), and a fivefold decrease in S. mutans expression after 3 weeks of use compared to baseline.
population_specificity: 154 participants divided into control and xylitol groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of xylitol and erythritol consumption on mutans streptococci (MS) levels and the oral microbiota.
results_summary: Xylitol consumption was associated with decreased MS levels in both children and adults, but no significant effects on the overall microbiota were observed. Erythritol showed no consistent effects on MS levels.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects (children and adults)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of synchronized neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) and chewing exercises on bite force and masseter muscle thickness in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that synchronized NMES and chewing exercises improved bite force and increased masseter muscle thickness in the studied population.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing spontaneous and chewing pain following initial orthodontic archwire placement.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant pain reduction between the LLLT and placebo groups at most time points, except for a modest reduction in chewing pain after 72 hours. The authors concluded that LLLT, with the tested parameters, was not effective for pain reduction in this context.
population_specificity: 26 patients (mean age 20.07 ± 3.13 years) with maxillary Little's Irregularity Index (LII) of 7 mm or more, indicating first maxillary premolars extraction, and no medication intake.
effective_dosage: Single LLLT dose (wavelength 830 nm, energy 2 J/point) applied to four points per maxillary anterior tooth root.
study_duration: Pain assessed at 1, 6, 24, 48, and 72 hours post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize disturbances in the oral microbiome related to oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC), particularly focusing on the impact of risky behaviors like betel quid chewing.
results_summary: The study identified significant alterations in bacterial diversity and abundance in OSCC lesions, including enrichment of Fusobacterium and loss of Streptococcus, and linked these changes to reduced production of tumor-suppressive metabolites. The findings were validated in an independent cohort, suggesting microbial signatures associated with oral cancer.
population_specificity: Male patients with cancers of the buccal mucosa (discovery cohort n = 74, validation cohort n = 42).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the masticatory capability of preschool children, comparing those with early childhood caries (ECC) to healthy controls, and evaluate the impact of ECC on food bolus granulometry.
results_summary: Children with ECC showed significantly reduced chewing frequency and increased food bolus particle size compared to healthy controls, indicating impaired masticatory function. The study also found higher NOT-S scores in the ECC group, particularly in the "Mastication and swallowing" domain.
population_specificity: Preschool children (13 with ECC, 13 with healthy oral conditions).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (natural foods: raw carrot, cheese, breakfast cereals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reliability and construct validity of the McGill Denture Satisfaction Questionnaire (MDSQ) for assessing patient satisfaction and masticatory ability in complete denture wearers.
results_summary: The study found high internal consistency and construct validity for the MDSQ, with two subsets—overall satisfaction and masticatory ability—showing strong reliability and single-factor dominance, explaining 54% and 65% of variance, respectively. Results were consistent across both U.S. and Brazilian samples.
population_specificity: Complete denture wearers (upper/lower dentures) from the U.S. (n=145) and Brazil (n=120).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of one-step versus two-step impression procedures for providing conventional complete dentures in edentulous individuals with severe mandibular resorption, focusing on masticatory performance, patient satisfaction, and post-delivery adjustments.
results_summary: Both impression methods resulted in similar masticatory performance, patient-reported satisfaction, and required the same number of post-delivery adjustments, indicating no significant difference between the two techniques.
population_specificity: Edentulous individuals with severe mandibular resorption requiring maxillary and mandibular conventional complete dentures.
study_duration: Outcomes assessed at 3 and 6 months after delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the masticatory efficiency of All-on-4 implant-supported dentures versus conventional complete dentures on Class I ridges using a color-mixing analysis test.
results_summary: Implant-supported fixed complete dentures showed superior masticatory efficiency compared to conventional dentures, particularly in early chewing cycles (5 and 10). Weight reduction differences between groups were not significant but notable in intercycle comparisons.
population_specificity: 10 patients with implant-supported fixed complete dentures and 10 patients with conventional complete dentures on Class I ridges (Atwood).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether gum chewing reduces postoperative ileus in patients undergoing open colorectal surgery.
results_summary: The study found that gum chewing had a significant to highly significant effect on reducing postoperative ileus-related outcomes, though the trials generally had weak designs. The authors recommend its use due to low risk of harm and cost.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing open colorectal surgery.

study_goal: The abstract does not mention Chewing or its effects.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide any results related to Chewing.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract discusses chronic pain patients but not in relation to Chewing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of diode laser versus electrocautery for removing inflammatory fibrous hyperplasia (IFH), particularly focusing on functional outcomes like chewing.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between diode laser and electrocautery in terms of transoperative or postoperative parameters, including functional alterations like chewing. Both methods were equally effective and safe for IFH removal.
population_specificity: 36 individuals (18 per group) with inflammatory fibrous hyperplasia, primarily denture wearers.
effective_dosage: Not specified (surgical techniques compared, not a supplement).
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up duration not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of escitalopram and moclobemide antidepressants in treating betel-quid chewing cessation (BQ-CC) among individuals with betel-quid use disorder (BUD).
results_summary: Escitalopram and moclobemide significantly improved BQ-CC rates compared to placebo, with adjusted proportion ratios of 6.3 and 6.8, respectively. Both treatments also reduced the frequency and amount of betel-quid intake by the 8th week.
population_specificity: 111 male patients with betel-quid use disorder (BUD).
effective_dosage: Escitalopram 10 mg/tab daily, moclobemide 150 mg/tab daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the clinical and pathological features of plexiform schwannomas in the oral cavity, including their association with symptoms like difficulty chewing.
results_summary: The study found that plexiform schwannomas in the oral cavity occasionally presented with difficulty chewing, though the primary symptom was typically a painless mass. Most cases were treated successfully with excision, with few recurrences.
population_specificity: 36 patients with plexiform schwannomas in the oral cavity (average age 28 years, female-to-male ratio 1.4:1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of replacing failing maxillary implants with implant-supported overdentures, including assessing chewing function.
results_summary: Chewing soft and tough food was rated as 'good,' while hard food was rated as 'moderate.' Patient satisfaction with overdentures was high, and overall implant survival was 95.7%.
population_specificity: Patients with failing maxillary implants after full arch rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the Edmonton-33 instrument for measuring functional outcomes, including chewing, in patients with head and neck cancer.
results_summary: The study found a moderate correlation between the Edmonton-33 instrument and chewing outcomes (r = -0.45), with factor loading values for chewing-related items being strong (0.77). The instrument demonstrated reliability in assessing chewing function among the studied population.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18+ with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (oral cavity, oropharynx, hypopharynx, larynx), at least 1 year post-treatment, and no active disease recurrence.
study_duration: Data collection spanned from July 1, 2013, to June 30, 2016 (3 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare stress levels on a fracture site between lag screw and miniplate fixation systems under simulated chewing forces.
results_summary: The lag screw model showed significantly higher stress values (4 times higher) compared to the miniplate model, but both systems were deemed clinically acceptable under chewing forces.
population_specificity: Not specified (patient CT-derived model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of gum chewing as part of enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) protocols for preventing postoperative ileus in radical cystectomy patients.
results_summary: Gum chewing was one of the most common measures (46% of protocols) to prevent postoperative ileus. The meta-analysis showed significant benefits of ERAS protocols, including reduced length of stay, complications, and time to defecation, though gum chewing's specific contribution was not isolated.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing radical cystectomy (surgical removal of the bladder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chewing gum for preventing oral mucositis in pediatric cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that chewing gum was not effective for preventing oral mucositis in pediatric patients with hematological or solid cancers treated with chemotherapy. A guideline against its use was established.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with hematological or solid cancers receiving chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enhanced chewing (via chewing gum intervention) could improve glycaemic control in women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: The study found no significant impact of chewing gum on postprandial glucose levels, with no clinically meaningful differences between the intervention and control groups. OGTT levels at 60 and 120 minutes were associated with glucose levels after breakfast, but overall, chewing did not significantly affect hyperglycaemia in GDM patients.
population_specificity: Women with recent diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
effective_dosage: Not specified (chewing gum intervention, but exact dosage/frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Five days (SMBG performed for five days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether steroid supplementation after TMJ arthrocentesis was more effective than placebo in reducing chewing pain and improving mandibular mobility in patients with unilateral TMJ pain.
results_summary: The steroid group showed significantly less chewing pain at 6 and 12 weeks compared to placebo, with greater pain-free mandibular opening and a higher proportion of patients achieving >50% improvement in chewing pain. Both groups experienced pain reduction over time, but steroid supplementation provided longer-lasting benefits.
population_specificity: Female patients with unilateral intra-articular TMJ pain who were unsuccessfully treated by usual therapy.
effective_dosage: Triamcinolone acetonide (steroid) infused into the superior joint space (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing gum before surgery could reduce postoperative sore throat (POST) in patients using a supraglottic airway device.
results_summary: Chewing gum significantly reduced the incidence and severity of POST within 24 hours after surgery, particularly in patients with pharyngeal mucosal injury. The gum group also had fewer instances of blood stains on the airway device compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients requiring general anesthesia via a streamlined liner of the pharyngeal airway (SLIPA) for hysteroscopic surgery lasting <60 minutes.
effective_dosage: Chewing gum for 2 minutes before anesthesia induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of medicated chewing gum as an innovative drug delivery system, focusing on its convenience and therapeutic benefits.
results_summary: The study highlights that therapeutic chewing gum offers a suitable and convenient method for dosing medications, especially for children and elderly populations, with advantages over conventional drug delivery systems. It also notes ongoing development and patent filings in this area.
population_specificity: Children and elderly populations, though broader applications are implied.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of new complete dentures on self-perceived masticatory ability and oral health-related quality of life in frail and nonfrail elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that new complete dentures improved masticatory ability for certain foods (lettuce and peanuts) in frail elders and enhanced psychological discomfort and handicap domains of oral health-related quality of life in both groups. Frail patients' handicap domain scores improved to match nonfrail levels post-treatment.
population_specificity: Completely edentulous elderly individuals, categorized as frail or nonfrail (n=10 per group).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was prosthetic treatment, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare chewing efficiency after immediate versus delayed loading of mini-implants used as supplementary support for removable partial dentures (RPDs).
results_summary: Immediate loading of mini-implants improved chewing efficiency significantly compared to delayed loading after 4 months. Both groups showed substantial improvement in chewing efficiency after housings were picked up, with similar results after 1 year.
population_specificity: Patients with RPDs in arches with unfavorable tooth distributions (no canine and at most two posterior teeth in one or both quadrants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the risks of smoke-free nicotine and tobacco products, including chewing tobacco, during pregnancy compared to smoking or no nicotine use.
results_summary: The study found that smoke-free nicotine products likely increase the risk of negative birth outcomes but less than smoking, though precise risk estimates remain uncertain due to epidemiological limitations.
population_specificity: Pregnant women using smoke-free nicotine or tobacco products.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review food products, including chewing gum containing liquorice, that might increase blood pressure and contribute to hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that chewing gum containing liquorice can cause clinically significant increases in blood pressure due to glycyrrhetic acid, which affects mineralocorticoid receptor activation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of food products and their effects on blood pressure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the effects of antidepressant therapy on betel-quid abstinence in patients with depression.
results_summary: The study found a 26% prevalence of betel-quid chewing among depressed patients, with chewers showing more severe depressive symptoms. Antidepressant therapy reduced betel-quid addictiveness by 4 times, suggesting potential for cessation therapy.
population_specificity: 204 patients with depressive disorders

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critique diagnostic and therapeutic pitfalls in managing Oral Submucous Fibrosis (OSMF) linked to areca nut chewing and propose an inter-professional model to improve outcomes.
results_summary: The study highlights the high morbidity and malignant transformation rate of OSMF due to areca nut chewing, noting no significant improvements in prognosis despite ongoing efforts. It critiques common management deficiencies in developing countries.
population_specificity: Individuals in South and South East Asian countries affected by OSMF, primarily due to areca nut chewing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether gum chewing reduces pain and anxiety during intravenous (IV) cannulation in children.
results_summary: The study found that gum chewing significantly reduced pain levels during IV cannulation compared to standard care, though no significant difference in anxiety levels was observed. Nurses reported higher perceived anxiety levels in children than the children themselves reported.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 to 12 years in a general pediatric unit in Turkey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an anesthetic chewing gum (ACG) could reduce initial pain/discomfort from orthodontic separator placement compared to regular chewing gum or no intervention.
results_summary: The ACG significantly reduced pain/discomfort compared to the control and regular chewing gum groups, with effects lasting up to 8 hours post-placement. The study concluded that ACG could eliminate initial discomfort and reduce the need for systemic analgesics.
population_specificity: 60 subjects receiving orthodontic elastomeric separators.
study_duration: 8 hours (pain assessed at 0, 1, 4, and 8 hours post-placement)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate self-reported oral health factors, including chewing ability, and their associations with clinical measures in cognitively healthy centenarians.
results_summary: Most centenarians reported good chewing ability (65%), with no significant differences between dentate and edentulous individuals. No relationship was found between cognitive functioning and chewing ability.
population_specificity: Cognitively healthy centenarians (aged 100+ years, 74% female) from the Dutch 100-plus Study cohort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient experiences, including chewing ability, between clear aligner therapy and conventional fixed orthodontic appliances.
results_summary: Patients using clear aligners reported significantly better chewing ability and no food restrictions compared to those with fixed appliances, though they experienced more speech difficulties.
population_specificity: 60 adult patients (30 per group) matched for age, treatment modality, and orthodontist.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the physicochemical adaptations and biomechanical changes in dentoalveolar joints due to functional loads (chewing) in both healthy and diseased states.
results_summary: The study found that physiologic chewing loads maintain biomechanical balance in healthy dentoalveolar joints, while pathologic loads disrupt stiffness gradients, leading to joint degradation. Spatiotemporal maps of physicochemical changes can guide targeted therapies for tissue regeneration.
population_specificity: Human periodontal complex and small-scale vertebrates (in vivo models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between mandibular prognathism (MP) and brain function by measuring brain blood flow (BBF) during chewing and calculation tasks.
results_summary: The study found that MP patients had fewer occlusal contacts and lower masseter muscle activity compared to those with normal occlusion. Chewing increased BBF in the inferior frontal gyrus in both groups, but the increase was smaller in MP patients, suggesting MP negatively affects brain function.
population_specificity: 17 subjects with normal occlusion (NORM) and 25 patients with mandibular prognathism (MP).

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of standardized home exercise jaw opening and chewing programs, as well as oral hygiene measures, on patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Jaw opening, chewing time, and oral hygiene significantly improved after 2 months (6%, 49%, and 25%, respectively) and remained significant after 4 months. No significant changes occurred during the 2-month control period without intervention.
population_specificity: 29 patients with moderate to advanced Parkinson's disease (median age 65), some with deep brain stimulation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (individualized dental hygiene instruction, jaw opening training, and lip/chewing exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of chewing gum (specifically 0.6% eucalyptus chewing gum) compared to placebo in managing halitosis due to oral diseases.
results_summary: The evidence for 0.6% eucalyptus chewing gum's effect on dentist-reported organoleptic test (OLT) scores was very uncertain, with no significant difference compared to placebo. No data were reported for patient-reported outcomes or adverse events.
population_specificity: Adults aged 17 to 77 years with halitosis due to oral diseases.
effective_dosage: 0.6% eucalyptus chewing gum (specific frequency not mentioned).
study_duration: Short-term follow-up (ranging from one week to four weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and categorize feeding and gastrointestinal anomalies, including chewing disorders, in individuals with Down syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that chewing disorders were present in 13 of 19 children with Down syndrome under 4 years old, indicating a significant prevalence of functional feeding difficulties in this population.
population_specificity: Individuals with Down syndrome, particularly children under 4 years old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current technological approaches to monitoring energy intake, including chewing rate as part of eating action unit (EAU) sensors, and to make recommendations for improving energy intake estimation.
results_summary: The study highlighted that EAU-based sensors, such as those measuring chewing rate, show promise but face challenges like understanding system success/failure, privacy-protecting ground truth methods, and food categorization uncertainty.
population_specificity: Population health researchers, engineers, and intervention developers from 6 universities and the National Institutes of Health.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify oral health factors associated with oral health-related quality of life (OHQoL) in people aged 65 years or older.
results_summary: OHQoL in older adults is positively associated with functional dentition (natural or prosthetic) and negatively associated with poor chewing ability, xerostomia, and orofacial pain. No consensus was found on the association between edentulism, caries, periodontal conditions, and OHQoL.
population_specificity: People aged 65 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify oral dysfunction, including chewing problems, in patients receiving treatment for head and neck cancers (HNCs).
results_summary: The study found that chewing problems were among the most common oral dysfunctions in HNC patients, with factors like cancer stage, tumor location, and treatment modalities influencing dysfunction. Interventions showed some improvement, but evidence was inconclusive.
population_specificity: Patients receiving treatment for head and neck cancers (HNCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a case of Traumatic Ulcerative Granuloma with Stromal Eosinophilia (TUGSE) and its diagnostic challenges, particularly in mimicking malignancy or infectious diseases.
results_summary: The study found that TUGSE can resemble malignant or infectious conditions, necessitating biopsy and clinical examination for accurate diagnosis. The lesion resolved spontaneously without recurrence after 26 months.
population_specificity: A patient with a solitary ulcer on the lower left retromolar buccal plane.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether botulinum toxin type A (BTX-A) injections in masticatory muscles could improve oral functions like chewing in individuals with cerebral palsy (CP) and bruxism.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of BTX-A compared to placebo on oral capacities at the group level, though most patients requested continued BTX-A treatment. Oral function varied widely among CP patients and over time, with no strong correlation between subjective and objective measures.
population_specificity: 12 patients with cerebral palsy and bruxism, compared to matched healthy references.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the analgesic effects of photobiomodulation (PBM) on pain and inflammatory cytokines related to orthodontic treatment, specifically during chewing and biting.
results_summary: The study expects PBM to reduce perceived pain and inflammatory cytokines in orthodontic patients compared to a sham group, though final results are pending.
population_specificity: 72 individuals receiving elastomeric separators on maxillary first molars.
effective_dosage: Single application of PBM (Ga-Al-As laser, 808 nm wavelength, 100 mW output power).
study_duration: Single intervention at separator placement, with pain assessed after one hour.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current knowledge on the development and regeneration of orofacial muscles, particularly in relation to chewing, swallowing, and speech, and compare them to trunk and limb muscles.
results_summary: The study found that orofacial muscles, including those involved in chewing, have lower regenerative ability and develop more fibrosis than other skeletal muscles, suggesting a need for targeted approaches to improve regeneration and reduce fibrosis.
population_specificity: Individuals with orofacial congenital defects, reconstructions, or trauma affecting muscle regeneration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of bone marrow nucleated cell (BMNc) injection versus hyaluronic acid (HA) injection in improving clinical outcomes, including chewing efficiency, in patients with degenerative temporomandibular joint disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: The BMNc group showed significantly better pain relief, chewing efficiency, and maximum interincisal opening compared to the HA group after 6 and 12 months, though no MRI evidence of cartilage regeneration was observed.
population_specificity: Patients with unilateral TMD and internal derangement (30 participants, 15 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether orofacial myofunctional therapy could improve chewing, swallowing, and breathing in patients with asthma and rhinitis, leading to better clinical control of these conditions.
results_summary: The study found very low evidence of improvement in functional control and clinical asthma scores, concluding no significant scientific support for the efficacy of orofacial myofunctional therapy in improving chewing, orofacial function, or nasal breathing in these patients.
population_specificity: Patients with asthma and rhinitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review genomic analyses of oral squamous cell carcinomas (OSCC) and explore how these studies inform on the biological mechanisms underlying OSCC, including the role of risk habits like betel quid chewing.
results_summary: The study found that OSCC is associated with lifestyle risk habits, including betel quid chewing, and identified specific genetic mutations (e.g., FAT1, CASP8, CDKN2A, NOTCH1) more prevalent in OSCC. It also highlighted molecular subtypes of OSCC that may respond differently to therapies, including immunotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with oral squamous cell carcinomas (OSCC), particularly those with lifestyle risk habits such as smoking, alcohol consumption, and betel quid chewing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate infection prevention challenges in dental laboratories, focusing on traditional and computer-aided technologies, and their implications for patient safety.
results_summary: The study highlights gaps in infection prevention guidelines for dental laboratories, contamination risks with traditional methods, and potential advantages of digital technology in reducing cross-infection, though challenges like scanner reconditioning and data protection remain.
population_specificity: Dental offices and dental laboratories handling dental impressions, casts, and appliances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of hyaluronic acid (HA) injection alone versus arthrocentesis plus HA injection for treating disc displacement with and without reduction, focusing on chewing-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that both treatments improved chewing efficiency and other symptoms, with arthrocentesis plus HA showing superior results in chewing efficiency and quality of life compared to HA alone. No improvements were observed in control groups.
population_specificity: 90 patients (116 TMJs) aged 15-82 years with disc displacement with or without reduction.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the role of chewing as a trigger for debilitating pain in patients with trigeminal neuralgia (TN).
results_summary: The study found that minimal stimulation, including chewing, can trigger severe pain in TN patients. Treatment options for TN include medications, surgery, and emerging neuro-modulatory techniques.
population_specificity: Patients with trigeminal neuralgia (TN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different motor neurotizers (cross-face nerve graft, spinal accessory nerve, and masseter nerve) in facial reanimation using gracilis functioning free muscle transplantation.
results_summary: The study found that the spinal accessory and masseter nerve groups showed higher initial smile excursion scores, but by 3 years, the cross-face nerve graft group achieved superior outcomes in spontaneity and overall evaluation scores. The masseter nerve group had limited long-term improvement, while spinal accessory nerve results were intermediate.
population_specificity: 392 patients with facial paralysis or postparalysis facial synkinesis (1985-2017).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the safety and adverse effects of botulinum toxin type A (BoNT-A) in treating myofascial pain and trigeminal neuralgia, particularly focusing on its tolerability and pain improvement.
results_summary: BoNT-A was well tolerated and improved pain in all included studies, with minor adverse effects like temporary regional weakness and injection site tenderness, which typically resolved spontaneously. The treatment showed consistent efficacy across studies, though future research is needed to assess safety with multiple applications or higher doses.
population_specificity: Participants with myofascial pain in masticatory muscles or trigeminal neuralgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate the effectiveness of maternal and child oral health interventions, including the use of fluoridated chewing gum, in MENA countries.
results_summary: The study found that interventions using fluoridated chewing gum (Saudi Arabia) and other oral health measures (Syria, Iran) were significantly effective in reducing early child caries (ECC). Integration of oral health promotions into vaccination programs also showed effectiveness.
population_specificity: Mothers and children in Syria, Saudi Arabia, and Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and tolerability of e-cigarettes versus nicotine gum for smoking cessation.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in smoking cessation effectiveness between e-cigarettes and nicotine gum, but e-cigarettes showed better tolerability with fewer adverse events. Smoking reduction rates were higher in the e-cigarette group at 24 weeks.
population_specificity: 150 subjects randomly assigned to e-cigarette or nicotine gum groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to categorize and summarize management recommendations from published enhanced recovery protocols (ERPs) for reducing post-operative ileus (POI) and improving gastrointestinal (GI) function after colorectal surgery, including the use of chewing gum.
results_summary: Chewing gum was one of the most commonly recommended interventions (35.1% of ERPs) for reducing POI, though high-quality evidence supporting its efficacy was not referenced. The study noted geographical trends in intervention recommendations but found weak evidence overall for most interventions, including chewing gum.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing colorectal surgery.
